---
title: 'Dilemmas and deliberations in managing the care trajectory of elderly patients
  with complex health needs: a single-case study'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-LT352CES" class="csl-bib-container">

Dilemmas and deliberations in managing the care trajectory of elderly patients with complex health needs: a single-case study. <i>BMC Health Services Research</i>, <i>22</i>(1). <a href="https://doi.org/10.1186/s12913-022-08422-3">https://doi.org/10.1186/s12913-022-08422-3</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-LT352CES" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-LT352CES" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Kumlin et al. conducted a study focusing on the challenges faced by elderly patients with complex health needs, their families, and healthcare professionals. As people live longer with multiple chronic illnesses, they require support from various healthcare services. However, healthcare systems are becoming more specialized and fragmented, making it difficult to coordinate care effectively. The study highlights the dilemmas and decisions these groups encounter while navigating the healthcare system. Understanding these challenges is important because it can lead to better policies and practices that ensure integrated and person-centered care. This research is crucial for improving the healthcare experience for elderly patients and their families, ensuring they receive the comprehensive support they need.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-LT352CES" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Ageing Population, Chronic Illnesses, Multimorbidity, Healthcare Services, Integrated Care, Person-Centred Services
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-LT352CES" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    Today, the ageing population is larger than ever before, and people who are living longer with chronic illnesses and multimorbidity need support from multiple healthcare service levels. Similarly, healthcare systems are becoming increasingly specialised and fragmented. The World Health Organization has highlighted novel policies for developing integrated and person-centred services. However, patients, next of kin and health professionals face several challenges in managing healthcare during the care trajectory. Limited literature has addressed the challenges experienced by these groups. Therefore, this study aimed to identify the dilemmas and deliberations faced by patients, next of kin and health professionals during the care trajectory of elderly patients with complex healthcare needs.
  </article>
